Wait, maybe the user is referring to a standard question where the options I, II, III are common disadvantages. Let me recall. Longitudinal studies follow the same subjects over time. Common disadvantages include things like participant attrition (people dropping out over time), which can lead to biased results. Another is the time and cost involved, as these studies take years. Also, there might be issues with changes in the environment or societal factors that affect the results. 

So if the options I, II, III are, for example, "I. Attrition, II. Cost, III. Confounding variables," then the answer would depend on which ones are considered disadvantages. But since the user hasn't provided the actual options, I need to make an educated guess based on standard knowledge.
